Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable, oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the UNOLS fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. The ship was delivered in 2014 and has completed three years of funded operations. UAF requests funds to purchase and install shipboard scientific support equipment that would be custom engineered to enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2017, R/V Sikuliaq completed 271 days, 178 (66%) of which were for NSF. In 2018, the vessel is scheduled to sail 249 days with 63% (157 days) of the schedule for NSF. With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment:

Underwire winch capability $39,516
Re-engineering lebus shell $20,000
Re-engineering storage drum $124,210
Dynamometer $5,985
$189,711

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The R/V Sikuliaq made two major improvements to its overside handling capabilities for conducting science operations. The first was accomplished by modifying the starboard knuckle boom crane to accommodate a second hydraulic winch on the underside of the jib boom. The stainless-steel winch with automatic brake is fully integrated with the crane's control system, and is designed to deploy, cast, tow, profile, or recover lightweight packages (< 600 lbs) such as buoys, gliders, nets, sediment grabs, and small CTDs. The winch can payout or haul-in up to 1 meter per second, and can run either a 3,000 ft length of 3/16" Yale Ultrex synthetic rope or an 1,150 ft length of 1/4" synthetic electromechanical cable. The diamond-screw level wind has sprocket sets for spooling in either a crossover or single-thread configuration. The drum features an access hatch, and the stub shaft is drilled out for mounting a slip ring. Since the installation was completed in September 2019, the underwire winch has been utilized on virtually every science cruise since. It has been praised by several PIs for increasing the operational efficiency of the vessel.

The second improvement was to add a subsea fiber optic capability by modifying one of the vessel's traction winch storage drums in order to accommodate a large electro-optical slip ring assembly. There is a space limitation on the outside of the drum that made this challenging, so we went with a design where the slip ring would be partially inserted inside the drum. This required a new drum flange with a wider register, a double-sided stub shaft, pillow-block bearing, and stanchion bracket. The storage drum now accepts fiber optic rotary joints with three single-mode passes, as well as a slip ring with four channels up to 3 kilovolts at 20 amps. Following the upgrade, in 2020 Sikuliaq spooled on a 10 km length of .681 power-optic cable, which now provides an in-house capability for remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) like Jason, or other tow vehicles that require fiber optic telemetry.
